description: From Latin nauseātus, from nauseō, from nausea, from Ancient Greek ναυσία (nausía), from ναῦς (naûs), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)neh₂-. Its surface etymology is nausea (queasiness, uneasiness, sickness) + -ate.

verbs.description: nauseate (third-person singular simple present nauseates, present participle nauseating, simple past and past participle nauseated)

examples: […]  this room, where misfortune seems to ooze, where speculation lurks in corners, and of which Madame Vauquer inhales the warm, fetid air without being nauseated.
[…]  I have not treated you as a Wise man would have done in silence, but it is time to put an end to this tittle tattle which has nauseated you for three days together.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To become squeamish; to feel nausea; to turn away with disgust.
examples: As one of Woodward’s Patients, sick and sore,
I puke, I nauseate,—yet he thrusts in more;

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To reject or spit (something) out because it causes a feeling of nausea.
examples: In Children and delicate Persons, who are apt to nauseate this Remedy, I have with Success given it mix’d up with thin Chocolate; which, if sufficiently sweetened, disguises it better than any thing I know of.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive, figurative) To be disgusted by (something).
examples: Old Age, with silent pace, comes creeping on,
Nauseates the Praise, which in her Youth she won,
And hates the Muse by which she was undone.
